Comment: Countries need to vote to invoke Article 5, meaning they need to decide if this harm was an attack.  During the Chernobyl disaster, a lot of radiation spread as far west as West Germany. But no one considered invoking Article 5 because it was clear that Chernobyl was not an attack against any NATO country.  The point of NATO is not to retaliate to every source of damage, it's to make sure if anyone does something to a member at the scale of war, they have a community who will defend them. Libya blew up a British flight and NATO did not invoke article 5. Al Qaeda blew up the world trade center and the pentagon and NATO did invoke article 5 for the first and only time.   It's not purely about harm being done, it's a question of "is this war?" The US felt after 9/11 that this was war and everyone agreed. Britain did not consider it war when they were attacked. So the key would be "should we consider the war attacking NATO members directly or is this not a direct attack on us?"
